pico.title: Data Governance for Satellite-Based Forest Monitoring in Indigenous Territories: A Scoping Review
pico.population: Satellite-based forest monitoring data covering indigenous territories, including deforestation alerts, fire detection, land use change classification, illegal mining and logging detection, and infrastructure encroachment monitoring in areas inhabited by indigenous peoples, including uncontacted or voluntarily isolated groups
pico.intervention: Data governance approaches integrating indigenous data sovereignty principles with satellite monitoring, including consent-based access controls, spatial masking of culturally sensitive areas, indigenous-controlled data repositories, tiered alert systems with indigenous community notification priority, CARE principles implementation (Collective benefit, Authority to control, Responsibility, Ethics), and co-designed monitoring protocols
pico.comparison: Open publication of all monitoring alerts (e.g., Global Forest Watch model), government-controlled access without indigenous consultation, complete restriction of indigenous territory data from external access, and external researcher-controlled access
pico.outcome: Effectiveness of forest protection and illegal activity deterrence, respect for indigenous data sovereignty and CARE principles, usability for indigenous-led territorial monitoring and governance, prevention of unauthorized access to locations of uncontacted peoples and sacred sites, community satisfaction and trust, and sustainability of monitoring partnerships
pico.research_question: For satellite-based forest monitoring in indigenous territories, how do different data governance approaches balance effective deforestation and illegal activity detection with indigenous data sovereignty and protection of culturally sensitive locations?
pico.rationale: Indigenous territories contain approximately 80% of remaining biodiversity and are critical for climate mitigation. Satellite-based monitoring provides unprecedented capability for detecting deforestation and illegal activities threatening these lands. However, the same technology that enables protection can expose sensitive information: locations of uncontacted peoples, sacred sites, traditional resource areas, and patterns of indigenous land use. Indigenous communities have increasingly demanded data sovereignty over information about their territories. The tension between transparency for accountability and protection of indigenous interests requires governance approaches that have not been systematically evaluated. CARE principles (Collective benefit, Authority to control, Responsibility, Ethics) offer an emerging framework, but implementation evidence remains limited.

sub_questions.title: Alert System Design for Indigenous Territories
sub_questions.population: Deforestation and fire alert systems covering indigenous lands (Global Forest Watch, FIRMS, national systems)
sub_questions.intervention: Indigenous-first notification systems, tiered access with delays for external users, community-controlled alert filtering
sub_questions.comparison: Open immediate publication vs. indigenous-first notification vs. complete masking of indigenous areas
sub_questions.outcome: Response time to deforestation events, protection outcomes (hectares prevented), indigenous community control and satisfaction, external researcher/NGO access sufficiency
sub_questions.research_question: How do different alert notification and access models affect both protection outcomes and indigenous data sovereignty in forest monitoring systems?

sub_questions.title: Spatial Masking of Sensitive Sites
sub_questions.population: Satellite monitoring products covering areas with sacred sites, uncontacted peoples, or culturally sensitive locations
sub_questions.intervention: Spatial masking approaches (buffer zones, generalization, complete omission, access-controlled high-resolution with masked public version)
sub_questions.comparison: Different mask sizes, adaptive vs. fixed masking, indigenous-defined vs. externally-defined sensitive areas
sub_questions.outcome: Protection of sensitive locations from external discovery, impact on monitoring utility, indigenous control over masking decisions, potential for mask boundaries themselves to reveal information
sub_questions.research_question: What spatial masking approaches effectively protect sensitive indigenous sites while maintaining sufficient monitoring utility, and how should masking decisions be governed?

sub_questions.title: Indigenous-Led Monitoring Platforms
sub_questions.population: Community-based forest monitoring initiatives using satellite data (e.g., Rainforest Foundation, indigenous territorial monitoring)
sub_questions.intervention: Indigenous-controlled satellite data platforms with community-defined access rules and benefit-sharing
sub_questions.comparison: External NGO/researcher-controlled platforms providing data to communities vs. indigenous-controlled platforms
sub_questions.outcome: Indigenous technical capacity development, sustainability of monitoring programs, data quality and coverage, community ownership and continued participation, CARE principles compliance
sub_questions.research_question: How do indigenous-controlled satellite monitoring platforms compare to externally-managed platforms in achieving sustained forest protection while respecting data sovereignty?
